title: Jobs in Tech
summary: Learn key tech jobs, practice Present Simple and Present Continuous, improve pronunciation and create an elevator pitch about yourself.

units.title: Warm-up: Your job and IT
units.description: Answer a few questions about your current job and IT interests.

prompts: Do you want to work in IT? Why or why not?
Which IT jobs do you know?

llmCheck.systemPrompt: You are an English teacher for IT students. Analyze the student's answer about their job and IT interests. 1) Give a CEFR-like level estimate (A2/B1/B2) with one sentence justification. 2) Point out up to 3 typical grammar mistakes, especially with present tenses. 3) Suggest 2 simple tips for improvement. Answer in simple English.

units.title: Key jobs in tech
units.description: Learn the names of common jobs in tech and what they do.

words.definition: A person who writes and maintains computer programs.
words.example: I work as a software developer at a small startup.

words.definition: A person who tests software to find bugs and improve quality.
words.example: Our QA engineer checks each new feature before release.

words.definition: A person who helps developers and operations work together and automates deployment.
words.example: The DevOps engineer sets up CI/CD pipelines for the team.

words.definition: A person who analyzes data and builds models to help business make decisions.
words.example: A data scientist finds patterns in user behavior.

words.definition: A person who writes the text inside apps and websites to create a good user experience.
words.example: The UX writer creates clear messages for buttons and error messages.

words.definition: A developer who works on the part of the website that users see and interact with.
words.example: The frontend developer builds responsive layouts.

words.definition: A developer who works on the server side and business logic.
words.example: The backend developer builds APIs for mobile apps.

words.definition: A person who plans what the product should do and coordinates the team.
words.example: The product manager defines features for the next release.

words.definition: A person who plans deadlines, tasks and manages communication in a project.
words.example: The project manager tracks the progress of the sprint.

words.definition: A person who helps users solve technical problems.
words.example: The support engineer answers customers’ questions by email.

activities.prompt: Match the tech job to its description.

rightOptions: Tests software to find bugs and improve quality.
Helps developers and operations work together.
Writes the text in apps and websites.
Plans what the product should do.

units.title: Reading: Popular jobs in tech
units.description: Read a short article about five popular tech jobs.

reading.title: Popular Jobs in Tech
reading.text:
The tech industry is growing very fast. New jobs appear every year, and many of them do not require a traditional university degree. Here are five popular jobs in tech.

A data scientist works with large amounts of information. They collect, store and analyze data. Then they create models to help companies make better decisions.

A UX writer creates the text that you see inside websites and apps. This text must be clear, simple and helpful. When a UX writer does a great job, you do not notice the text — everything just feels easy to use.

A web developer builds websites and web applications. They usually work with HTML, CSS and JavaScript. Good web developers constantly learn new tools and frameworks.

A DevOps engineer helps developers release code faster and safer. They work with servers, cloud platforms and automation tools. Their goal is to shorten development time and improve communication between teams.

A blockchain developer creates applications that use blockchain technology. Many companies want to use blockchains because they are transparent and cost-efficient.

glossary.definition: Easy to see through or understand; clear.
Not expensive and giving good results.
A set of tools and libraries that helps developers build applications.

Five popular jobs in the tech industry.
Why you need a university degree for tech.

options: They design the visual layout of a website.
They test software and find bugs.

activities.prompt: In your own words, why do many companies want to use blockchain technology?

llmCheck.systemPrompt: You are an English teacher. The student answers a short question based on a reading text. 1) Check if the meaning is generally correct. 2) Give a score from 0 to 3. 3) Correct major grammar mistakes in one improved version. Answer shortly.

units.title: Grammar: Present Simple vs Present Continuous
units.description: Learn when to use Present Simple and Present Continuous, especially in work context.

explanation.text: Use Present Simple to talk about facts, habits and regular actions. Example: "I work as a QA engineer." Use Present Continuous to talk about actions happening now or temporary situations. Example: "I am working from home this week."
examples: She usually starts work at 9 a.m. (Present Simple – a regular action).
He is fixing a bug right now. (Present Continuous – happening now).

activities.prompt: Complete the sentences with the correct form: Present Simple or Present Continuous.

items.sentence: Chris and Steve ______ (play) Red Dead Redemption at the moment.
Our developer ______ (fix) a critical bug right now.
We ______ (work) from home this week because the office is closed.

activities.prompt: Generate extra practice based on student mistakes.

llmCheck.systemPrompt: You are a grammar tutor for IT English. The student completed several Present Simple vs Present Continuous sentences. Based on their mistakes, 1) explain one or two key rules in very simple English with 2 examples, 2) generate 5 new gap-fill sentences focusing only on these patterns, 3) provide correct answers.

units.title: Pronunciation: Tech jobs
units.description: Practice pronouncing common tech job titles.

activities.prompt: Record yourself saying at least five tech job titles from the list.

llmCheck.systemPrompt: You receive the ASR transcript and phoneme scores for the student's pronunciation of several tech job titles. Give short, friendly feedback in simple English and mention 1–2 words they should practice more.

units.title: Speaking: Introducing yourself at a tech meetup
units.description: Practice introducing yourself and your job in a role-play with the AI.

activities.prompt: Imagine you are at a tech meetup. Introduce yourself and talk about your job or the job you want in tech.

llmCheck.systemPrompt: You are a friendly English-speaking colleague at an IT meetup. Have a short conversation (7-10 turns) with the student about their job and IT interests. Ask simple follow-up questions. After the conversation, give short feedback: 1) what was good, 2) up to 3 mistakes with corrections, 3) 3 better phrases they can use next time.

units.title: Writing: Your elevator pitch
units.description: Write a short elevator pitch about yourself as a current or future IT professional.

activities.prompt: Write your elevator pitch (4–6 sentences) about your current or future job in tech.

llmCheck.systemPrompt: You are an English writing teacher for IT students. The student wrote an elevator pitch about themselves. 1) Correct grammar and word choice but keep their style. 2) Show the corrected version. 3) Highlight changes in brackets []. 4) Suggest one more advanced version and one simpler version. Keep each version 4-6 sentences long.
